raw_text:
England children's tsar appointed
 
 The first children's commissioner for England has been appointed.
 
 Great Ormond Street Hospital professor of child health, Al Aynsley-Green, was chosen by the government and will start the £100,000-a-year job immediately. He will oversee a £2.5m annual budget and have the power to look into "any matter relating to the interests and well-being of children". Prof Aynsley-Green has also been the national clinical director for children in the Department of Health. He promised to make sure that children's opinions "count".
 
 "I will be drawing on my experience of working with children and young people to help ensure that those with the power to improve children's lives do live up to their responsibilities. "I want all children and young people to know that they can approach me to discuss any matter that affects them, knowing that I will value their opinion." Education Secretary Ruth Kelly said Prof Aynsley-Green would "strengthen the voice of children and young people". Prof Aynsley-Green was a lecturer at Oxford University, trained at Guy's Hospital Medical School, University of London; Oriel College, Oxford; and in Switzerland. He is described as "a proud grandfather" of four. Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland already have children's commissioners.
llama3.2:1b: The first children's commissioner for England has been appointed, Al Aynsley-Green, a professor at Great Ormond Street Hospital who will oversee £2.5m annual budget. He can investigate any matter affecting children. Prof Aynsley-Green promises to listen to child opinions and value them.

Prof Aynsley-Green, formerly head of Great Ormond Street Hospital, will be paid £100,000 and use his experience to ensure children's voices are valued. He has previously worked with the Department of Health. This position follows similar roles established in Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland.

A former professor at Great Ormond Street Hospital and national clinical director for children, he will oversee a £2.5m budget and has promised to ensure children’s opinions are valued. Currently in his role as Education Secretary, Ruth Kelly praised him for "strengthening the voice of children and young people." Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland already have similar positions. Aynsley-Green is described as a proud grandfather with experience working with children and trained at various institutions including Oxford University, Guy's Hospital Medical School, and Oriel College.

He'll get £100k per year and start looking into children's issues. He was the national clinical director at Health Department, and he promises to make children's opinions count.

Also mentioned are Education Secretary Ruth Kelly's comments about him strengthening children's voice. Prof Aynsley-Green has a background from Oxford, Guy's Hospital, London, Oriel College, and Switzerland. He's described as a "proud grandfather."

There are plans in place for Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland already having commissions.

Prof Al Aynsley-Green, a professor of child health at Great Ormond Street Hospital, will be chosen by the government to oversee a £100,000-a-year job, overseeing a £2.5m annual budget and having the power to investigate any matter relating to the children's well-being. He previously served as the national clinical director for children in the Department of Health. Prof Aynsley-Green promised that children's voices will be valued. Education Secretary Ruth Kelly will highlight his role in strengthening children's voice. Prof Aynsley-Green has a background from Oxford, Guy's Hospital, London, Oriel College, and Switzerland, known as a "proud grandfather." Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland already have their own children's commissioners.
